replies.bodyText:
My thought here was that the refactoring in this PR was a superset of the suggest recon-only client. Is that not true? What special requirements does reconciliation have? The code that I thought the comment was referring to is just a single line now.
The Create Project streaming is a slightly different use, but it's already accommodated in the current code.
I can add a version of the comment back if it's still relevant, but perhaps we should update it to reflect the current state of affairs.
replies.author: tfmorris

replies.bodyText:
I was thinking about a java library to query reconciliation services. You would be able to construct a reconciliation query with POJOs and send it to a service described by a URL (without having to worry about the JSON serialization of that reconciliation query, for instance). This is more high-level than a HTTP library: it would abstract away the specifics of how reconciliation clients and servers communicate over HTTP.
Such a library could also be the basis of a framework to build reconciliation services.
replies.author: wetneb

replies.bodyText: That sounds like it has very little, if anything to do with OpenRefine, but I'll put the comment back with a clarification that it's talking about a 3rd party library.

timeline.message:
Update to Apache HTTP Client 5.x

Adds support for Retry-After headers, HTTP/2, and a bunch of
other stuff under the covers, but this is a straight 1:1
replacement without any functional changes unless provided
by the default settings.

Fix request delay calculation & add more retries

Moves request delay to a request interceptor and fixes calculation
of the delay (again).

Increase retries from 1x to 3x and use delay*2 as the default
retry interval, if no Retry-After header
Use IOException instead of Exception for HTTP errors

Refactor HTTP code into a common utility class

Centralizes the six (slightly) different implementations to use
a common Apache HTTP Client 5 implementation which implements our
strategies for retries, timeouts, error handling, etc.
